title: 108_hr1874
content: The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" clarifies the definition of homebound through a demonstration project. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" establishes a demonstration project for Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions to receive home health services if they are deemed homebound. Eligibility criteria include a permanent and severe condition, requiring assistance with daily living activities, and needing home health services. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" sets up a Medicare demonstration project for home health services for homebound beneficiaries with chronic conditions. The project collects data on quality of care, patient outcomes, and costs to Medicare. Reports to Congress are required within one year of implementation. The Secretary will submit reports to Congress on the Medicare demonstration project for home health services, using data collected under subsection (c). Waiver authority allows the Secretary to waive compliance with certain requirements of the Social Security Act for the project. Nothing in this section waives penalties for prohibited acts under the Social Security Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Medicare demonstration project for home health services under the Social Security Act. The term "medicare beneficiary" is defined as an individual entitled to benefits under part A or enrolled under part B of the Act. The term "home health services" refers to services defined in section 1861(m) of the Social Security Act. "Activities of daily living" include eating, toileting, transferring, bathing, and dressing. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF THE DEFINITION OF HOMEBOUND FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR HOME HEALTH SERVICES UNDER MEDICARE. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF THE DEFINITION OF HOMEBOUND FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR HOME HEALTH SERVICES UNDER MEDICARE. Sections 1814(a) and 1835(a) of the Social Security Act are amended to allow individuals with permanent severe conditions requiring assistance with daily living activities to receive home health services without disqualification based on absences from home. The amendments made by subsection (a) clarify the definition of homebound for eligibility for home health services under Medicare. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to submit a report on a demonstration project analyzing its effect on home health services by December 1, 2006. If no finding is included in the report, the project will be discontinued on January 1, 2007. The clarification of the definition of homebound for Medicare home health services will become effective on January 1, 2007, unless data shows adverse effects or unreasonable expenditure increases directly caused by the clarification. If such findings are included in the report, specific data on expenditure increases must be provided. The text discusses recommendations to exempt permanently and severely disabled homebound beneficiaries from restrictions on absences to qualify for home health services under the Medicare program. Technical amendments are also mentioned for Sections 1814(a) and 1835(a) of the Social Security Act. The text discusses amending Section 1814(a) of the Social Security Act to include leaving home and making technical changes to benefit provisions.
